transcript.sentence: Greetings to you all and nice to connect again as I welcome you to the presentation of ABB's third quarter results.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I'm Anto Finogh, Head of Ministerial Relations, and next to me here is our CEO, Björn Rosengren, and our CFO, Timo Jamotila.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: They will, as usual, take you through the presentation before we're up for the Q&A session.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: But before we begin, I should mention the information regarding safe hub notices and our use of non-gap measures on slide 2 of the presentation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Also, this call would include forward-looking statements which are based on the company's current expectations and certain assumptions and are therefore subject to risks and uncertainties.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And with that said, I will hand over to Björn and Timo later on for their quarterly comments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Anssi, and a warm welcome from me as well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I have to say I'm very pleased with our performance this quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The operation numbers show strength and verify that ABB is moving in the right direction, even faster than we originally had anticipated.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: You have probably already figured out that I'm very happy about the high margins of 16.6%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It looks like we likely will reach our margin targets one year early.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But I'm also pleased that we executed on our promises of portfolio management.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In my view, today's result is a good indication that we are improving operation performance to our new way of working.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Accountability, transparency and speed.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: To me, some proof points are our strong and broad price execution.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The record high margin, we have made division-led acquisitions, we divested non-core operations, and we completed the spin-off of Acceleron.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In short, we are making ABB a more focused and well-performing company with focus on being a technology leader in electrification and automation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: That said, we still have a couple of matters that need to be resolved.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: One such item is the Legacy Kusil project.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We now book the provision related to this, which impacted the EPS performance in the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We feel confident that there will not be any additional material provisions related to these matters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I will come back to this a little bit later.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Before we move on, I want to comment on e-mobility.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We have said that we want to list part of this company, and we remain committed to this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But given the high volatility in the capital markets, we do not see it happening this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We follow the market development closely, and we'll come back when we feel circumstances are right.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Now let's look more closely at orders and revenues on slide four.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In our results, FX, especially the continued strengthening of the dollar, was a big negative swing factor of nine to 10% when you compare our reported orders and revenues with the organic development.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But looking beyond that, we had another strong growth quarter with comparable orders up 16%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We saw a stable to positive development in most customer segments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Easing of component constraints will shorten delivery lead times, which should trigger a normalizing of the order pattern.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Still, it was another strong quarter for orders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It was actually the seventh consecutive period with a book-to-bill ratio above one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And our order backlog remains on a record high level.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Looking at the revenue chart on this slide, you see that this was one of the strongest quarters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Comparable growth was 18% with a positive development in all business areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: This reflects a strong price contribution.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But I was also pleased to finally see volumes released to a greater extent than in the previous quarters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Deliveries were held by better availability of electrical components.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Another positive was that our China's business faced less business disruptions from COVID lockdowns.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Now let's take a quick look at the different regions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Both America and Europe improved by 20% or more.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: They clearly outpaced the 4% growth in AMEA.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In America, the important U.S. market increased by 29% on a strong development across most segments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In Europe, orders increased in most of the major markets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: In the AMEA region, China declined by 2%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Three of our businesses areas saw a lower order in China, with only motion in positive territory.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Let's turn to slide six and our earnings outcome.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Gross margin is important, and I was pleased to see an improvement of 90 basic points to to 33.5%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The high volumes clearly helped, but also very good price execution of close to 7% for the group.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We increased operation EBITDA by 16%, but the underlying improvement was even stronger.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: If we exclude the negative effects, earnings were actually up by 27%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I already mentioned the strong margin of 16.6%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We achieved this through an impact from high volumes, good operational performance, and well-executed price management.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We are clearly becoming more efficient.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I mentioned the Concealed Project earlier.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: As reminder, this is the legacy project dating back to 2015.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And we are now finally resolving the remaining matters of this topic.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: This triggered a non-operational provision of 325 million in the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So on the back of this charge, despite our strong operational performance, EPS declined from last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We feel confident that there'll be not any more additional material provision related to these matters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Since the Kossilie case was reported, ABB has spent considerable time and efforts, including launching a new code of conduct, educating employees and implementing control system to prevent something similar to happen again.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It is very important that our stakeholders feel confident in ABB and our business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: With that, I hand over to Tim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Björn.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And greetings to everyone also from my side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: First, I want to connect to Björn's Kusile comment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Once this is resolved, I would say that besides the one non-core item of max 100 million of risk, which we have mentioned to you already before, we are now in normal course of business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Fundamentally changing ABB's risk profile has been a painful journey during past years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Now we are pretty much done.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We have a strong balance sheet, we have a net positive pension position, and we have not been doing EPC business in a while, and it is not coming back.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So we are in a good position going into 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Okay, let's then look at the performance in the business areas, which actually all contribute to comparable growth as well as earnings and margin improvement.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Starting with electrification, where we continue to see strong customer activity, which resulted in comparable orders being up 20%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking at the total picture, we saw strength in all customer segments and all regions improved at a double digit rate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: If you take a slightly more granular look, we actually saw softness in some segments in China, which declined by 4%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In Europe, Germany stood out in the sense that orders declined.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Germany is a distribution-led market and we saw distributors bringing inventories to what seemed to be a normalized going forward level.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I should also mention the very strong comparable order growth in the U.S. at 37%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: It was good to see that pricing a strong top line driver also in this quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But importantly, we now also saw volumes improving as a result of a generally strong market and easing of supply chain constraints.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: This helped momentum in customer deliveries, also in distribution solutions, which earlier has been hampered by semiconductor shortages.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In total, comparable revenues grew by 22%, percent, but still the order backlog increased to all-time high level of 6.8 billion as book-to-bill remained above 1. Electrification's operational EBITDA margin came in at a very strong 18 percent, the highest level in recent history.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: This was primarily driven by a good development in volumes and the continued strong price execution, which more than offset cost inflation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The margin expansion of 210 basis points admittedly included approximately 50 basis points tailwind from a two-years-old insurance claim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking ahead into the fourth quarter, we expect double-digit growth in comparable revenues and a seasonal pattern to repeat, meaning a sequentially lower operational EBITDA margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Let's then move on to motion on slide 8. orders again came in at around 2 billion despite the headwind from the stronger dollar.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In addition to a strong underlying market, the 24% comparable growth was also driven by large orders, including the approximately 170 million in traction orders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: A really good example on how we are supporting sustainable mobility in line with our purpose.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Our cutting-edge technology include high efficient traction converters and motors that will power more than 300 new trains reforcing Europe's railway network.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking at the revenue chart in the middle of this slide, you see a clear acceleration in comparable growth to 23%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In addition to the continued solid pricing execution, we now saw volumes contribute to growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Helped by strong demand, improved supply chain, as well as a sequential recovery in customer deliveries in China as COVID-related business disruptions eased.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The strong top-line development was also reflected in Motion's operational EBITDA margin of 17.8%, as higher volumes facilitated an improved fixed-cost absorption. absorption.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Price increases continued to offset the negative impact from higher input cost, but also a slight negative product mix which was triggered by high deliveries of electrical motors.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The margin increased by 40 basis points from last year, which is a strong outcome, also taking into account that this includes about 60 basis points dilution from the Dodge divestment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking ahead into the fourth quarter, motion is facing a challenging revenue comparable from last year, hence we anticipate a sequentially lower growth rate to comparable revenues.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We expect the operational EBIT R margin to decline slightly, a Q4 pattern you recognize from earlier years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Turning then to slide 9 and process automation, for which the underlying market activity continued to be strong.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Particular strength was noted in end markets like gas, mining and refining, while there was some signs of headwinds in the more energy-intense segment of the metals industry.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Services was up 12 percent.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: BA's total comparable order growth of 3 percent was impacted by the timing of customers placing orders, particularly in the energy industries and marine and ports divisions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Regionally, Europe and the Americas both saw high single-digit growth, while AMEA declined as China orders were down 11% from a high comparable from last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The sequential decline in the order backlog that you can see on this slide was mainly driven by FX movements.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In constant currencies, the order backlog increased compared with the end of the second quarter as the book-to-bill ratio remained above 1. Revenues grew 6% on a comparable basis with contribution from all five divisions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We did see a sequential easing of component shortages, but are not totally out of the woods yet.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking at profitability, you can see that the operational EBITDA margin reached the highest level in recent history at 15.3%, percent, expanding 160 basis points from last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: As a reminder, we have earlier mentioned to you that Turbo has roughly 180 basis points of its positive impact on the PA margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Higher volumes and mix were key drivers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But also some benefits from earlier taken efficiency measures.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: It is great to see that the team's conscious efforts to improve the the gross margin in the order backlog is now being realized in revenues.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The margin trajectory is clearly moving in the right direction.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking at the expectations for the fourth quarter, I note that PEA had very high revenues in Q4 last year, and consequently we anticipate a low or even slightly negative comparable revenue growth rate in Q4 this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We expect the operational EBITDA margin to be similar to last year's reported level, even excluding the high-margin Acceleron business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: On slide 10, we turn to robotics and discrete automation, where overall customer activity remained at a high level.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: That said, the lower comparable order growth reflects customers returning to a more normal order pattern as they seemingly anticipate the easing of supply chain constraints to shorten delivery lead times ahead.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In addition, there were some signs of customers taking slightly longer to place orders, but we still see a robust opportunity pipeline.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking at comparable revenues, it was good to see Aarei return to positive growth of 12% after having been held back by shortages of electrical components and COVID-related lockdowns in China in recent quarters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: While it is still no walk in the park, we would expect this improved supply situation to sustain and support deliveries from the backlog in both divisions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I'm also happy to say that the new robotics manufacturing site in Shanghai is now fully operational and volumes were transferred during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Similar to the other business areas, RA's profitability benefited from higher volumes and a positive price impact as the operational EBITDA margin increased by 170 basis points to 12.8%, underlined by both divisions in double-digit territory.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: For the fourth quarter, we expect an even stronger growth rate for comparable revenues than what we had in Q3, supporting some sequential margin improvement.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Moving to slide 11, showing the group operational EBITDA bridge.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: As you can see, the comparable earnings improvement benefited from our strong pricing execution and the recovery in volumes, which more than offset the adverse effects from from cost inflation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Acquisitions and divestments, i.e. mainly Dodge, as well as the impact from changing FX, were slightly diluting on a group level.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Let's now look at our cash flow on slide 12.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: It was good to see our back-end loaded cash flow expectations for the year coming through, with the third quarter cash from operating activities in continuing operations at 793 million.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Compared with last year, the cash impact from better operational performance was, however, more than offset by negative movements in trade working capital, the reasons primarily being a higher build-up in inventories and less favorable change in trade receivables to support strong continued order intake and higher revenue levels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In this quarter, we had a negative cash impact of about 125 million from the exit of one non-core legacy businesses, as announced in Q2.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Looking ahead, I want to remind you about a couple of items which will impact our future cash flows.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: First, Björn mentioned earlier the Kusile provision of about 325 million.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: This is expected to impact our cash flow in the coming quarters as we finalize the settlement.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: On a more positive note, we also receive about $1.4 billion in cash flow from investing activities from the sale of the remaining stake in Hitachi Energy as we expect to close the transaction now in Q4.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Now you have heard us talk about being more active on the M&A side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So before I hand over to Björn, let me briefly walk you through what we have done here.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We are actually picking up the pace.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Admittedly, they are small tickets, but this is natural since smaller tends to be easier to find and close.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The important thing is that our new processes work. the implementation of the ABB way, we have significantly changed how we work with M&A. First, we have increased the analytical discipline for acquisitions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Then, as a consequence of the decentralized ABB way operating model, we have transferred the responsibility to build the target pipeline to the divisions, i.e. close to the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Each division is different and has different investment needs to secure future growth. we firmly believe that this new setup will result in more focused and accurate growth activities.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We simply think that doing many smaller deals is better for the buyer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Björn mentioned earlier division-led acquisitions in this quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Motion announced their first two acquisitions in a long time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Both the Siemens Low Voltage NEMA motor business and the Powertech converter acquisition will help respective divisions to further cement their leading market positions and then looking at the grey dots on the right side of this slide you can see that we have also driven minority investment through our divisional lenses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Both the in-charge energy and numosity majority acquisitions made earlier this year are good examples that these minority investments can later also become acquisition targets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So in summary, I feel we are on the right track to drive value creation also through inorganic growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And with that, let me hand over to Björn to some final comments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Timo.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And lastly, on slide 14, we take a quick look at the expectations for Q4.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We expect the low double-digit comparable revenue growth impacted by the high level of revenues recorded last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The operational EBITDA margin is typically lower in Q4 compared with Q3, and we expect this pattern to repeat also this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We have had a good performance so far this year, and we are likely to achieve our margin targets already in 2022.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We will leave the 2023 targets unchanged.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And what we mean is that any normal market fluctuation should not prevent us from achieving our operational EBITDA margin of at least 15%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And with that, I'll let Ansi start the Q&A. Yes, let's open up for the Q&A.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And for those of you who have dialed in on the phone, you press start 14 to register to ask a question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And just as a reminder to secure the sound quality please do remember to mute the webcast as your line is open for questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: If you instead want to put your question through by using the online tool in the webcast, please type your question in the field in the bottom right corner of the screen and I will then put your question through from here.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I already see that we have a long queue for questions and as we really want to try and get through as many of you as possible I kindly ask you to this time limit you to one question per person and with that said I think we start off with a question from the conference call as we open up the line for Martin at Citi.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Are you there Martin?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Yes I'm here thank you for taking the question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: And if I'm limited to one, perhaps I could ask about the energy crisis impacts.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: You've touched on it a little bit in your opening remarks, but if we look at some of your end customers that are obviously energy intense, when we look at your process automation, you talk about a strong pipeline, even though the cost itself, perhaps not so much in the way of large orders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: How are you seeing this impacting your customers?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Should we think that basically creating an opportunity or you can support energy efficiency orders over the coming months or is it more of a concern that the impacts perhaps on capacity being scaled back in Europe and so forth could actually lead to demand destruction if you like in Europe and therefore more of a negative.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: So we're very interested to hear how you're looking at that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Yeah thanks Martin for the question maybe I'll take a crack at that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So first of all I just want to say that the energy intensity for ABB itself is quite low so this is like you know half a point point of our cost base so this really comes from the customer side as you mentioned and I think this is really a bit of a dual situation so yes we have some customers as we mentioned today like in the metals industry so if you think about something like aluminum smelters and that kind of stuff so very energy intense and on these these ones we are seeing a little bit of slowdown on the other hand because our products are really driving energy efficiency on the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We are seeing a lot of growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I mean, in some bit new areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Well, I just mentioned that in Middle East and Africa, we had like 50 percent type of order growth driven by energy.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And we are seeing this also in some parts of the U.S. market and so forth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So I don't think for us this is like a one answer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I think overall, I think we are pretty balanced on the situation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But we, of course, have to see how it plays out.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: We move on to Alex at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Alex, please, your line should be open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thanks very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Good morning, everyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Yes, okay, one question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I wondered if you could talk a little bit about your pricing then.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think you said 7 percent at the group level.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I wondered if you could expand a little bit around regional differences or comments perhaps around where you find that that pricing is, I guess, coming up against any pushback or any indication of any deterioration, deceleration in that regard.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Alex.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I can talk a little bit about the pricing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: As you probably know, we put in pricing strategy in each of our division already 2020 and pricing is not just lifting prices.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We work on value-based pricing concept and we have implemented these strategies in all our divisions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Of course, we are happy that we did it already then.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So when the inflation came, I think more or less all of our divisions was well prepared to handle that and I think that has been done and as you can see, we have been able to offset many of the cost increases that we have had during the last years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Of course, going forward, we see there are certain parts where we see inflation, we see some increases in cost even though it's getting a little bit better, I must say. rates are going down, some of the commodity prices are being more neutralized.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: On the other hand, energy prices are going up and the inflation is still there as you see on some of the numbers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So far, I think the divisions, which is this is a division that have done that in a quite professional way.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Going forward, I think that is actually dealt with all the divisions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So some of them will be more impacted, some less, and they need to deal with it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So I wouldn't say that's a general picture for whole ABB.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We can say though that US and Europe have bigger inflation than we've seen, for instance, in Asia.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Okay.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Very good.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And I will put through a question here that we've received online and it's from Jonathan Mounsey at Xen BNP Paribas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: He says, we are likely heading into a downturn next year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I would think that the efforts to decentralize over recent years will yield a very different set of behaviors within the group compared to previous slowdowns.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: In previous downturns, group management moved to announce company-wide restructuring plans.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: If demand softens now, how will things be different this time?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And I guess this is...
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I think maybe I should answer that question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Of course, we have a strong confidence in our new operating model, the ABB way, meaning we're moving the decision-making to all our businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: As you know, 99% of all our people are today working in our businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Now, we are not planning any kind of corporate activities when it comes to de-size the company.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I think already our divisions have been, since a half year back, been working with different scenario planning looking at different kind of softening of the market more heavily or just a little bit and they have made their plans based on that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Some divisions are more impacted and some will be less impacted and they will make these decisions in the businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: This is an operating model that works and we feel comfortable about that going if we will go into softer times going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So we open up for next question from the conference call, which should be coming from Gail Dolcebank.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thanks very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Good morning, everybody.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Can you hear me?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We can.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We do.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Okay.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: That's great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: I have a question on the order dynamics.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: I mean, if I try and adjust for seasonality, it appears that organic orders were up sequentially maybe by, you know, nearly 5%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So it clearly defies my expectations of some sort of normalization.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: I mean, I heard you, you know, talking about this normalization in discrete industries, but it appears that in all the segments, we've seen really a nice positive development.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So my question is, I mean, in which segments and in which regions in particular did you see the greatest positive developments sequentially speaking?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yeah, sequentially, I will start with this and thanks for the question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We more look at this year on year, but I think if you look at our sequential development, we are first of all seeing very strong development in the U.S. We had a very strong U.S. growth, close to 30% and also in some markets in Southern Europe we have been a very, very strong development in places like Italy, Spain, so forth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Also UK was this time strong.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We have very strong growth in India actually already two years in a row over 40% growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So these are some of the areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But I also, I mean this is of course orders, I understand not revenue, but we also were expecting a little bit of this happen going into the year that we would really have a strong performance in Q3, when we sort of come out from some of the constraints.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So these are some of the areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And then, as I mentioned earlier, we are seeing some strong OPEX demand on oil and gas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And we're also seeing strong demand in mining, industrial automation or industrial electrification continues very strong.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: If you look at the trends in motion in particular, we have now, I think, sequentially twice over 20 percent growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So these are some of the areas where it's coming through.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: The motion trend, I think, is really, really looking very strong, even if we had a bit more mix now on electric motors, but that seems to be continuing on a good trajectory.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Okay, thanks, Gael.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: We take the next question from the conference call and we open up the line for Ben at Morgan Stanley.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: I hope all are well, and thank you for taking the question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Really, it's for Bjorn, and it's more color, it's a local sense of what's going on in China.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: If we think about the order development during the quarter, which areas do you see as relatively strong?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: I'm assuming motion was the best, but if you can just give us a feel for which were the relative areas of strength and weakness.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And I guess similarly, how did the kind of base orders trend throughout the quarter?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: So were things accelerating in China during 3Q?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Ben.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: If you look at China, you're seeing the orders in North America, you're seeing in Europe and somewhat weaker in Asia.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And China was down a couple of percent. is of course mainly driven by the residential construction market, which is, as we all know, the weakest one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We are somewhat stronger on the industrial part of the businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It varies a little bit between our different businesses, where I think the one sticking out most positively is Motion, actually.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We had a very strong position during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I mean then if you look at on the robot and discrete automation, you know China is our biggest robot market and it was down a little bit during the quarter, but at the same time we should know that we have an order book which is up 80% on that part, so we are normalizing a little bit on the order side there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I mean going forward, we are not so nervous about China, we think it is moving on and we expect not to see any huge growth number, but pretty steady going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Yeah, maybe just comment on the base orders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: They were actually very similar now this quarter, so there is no big delta on the base orders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: In Germany, we had a bit of a delta because we had a large order, but this dynamic was not there regarding China this time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: That's helpful.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Okay.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Ben.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And then we open up for a question from Guillermo at UBS.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Hi.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Good morning, everyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Thank you for taking my question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: I guess maybe I wanted to elaborate on the segments within electrification.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: I guess you gave very clear country and regional picture, but I was wondering whether you describe a little bit the growth patterns that you've seen in the industrial infrastructure, non-residential, which I think will be tested.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And then similarly, you know, about cancellations, do you think that there is an increase in risk in cancellations coming from any of the points in the backlog or any of the additional backlog?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Yeah, thanks, Guillermo.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Maybe I'll at least start this one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So first of all, on electrification, it's a broad-based strong demand.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So I would say this China topic, what Björn was discussing, is pretty much the only area where we are seeing a bit lower growth, and as you saw, we had over 20% both order growth and revenue growth, so it's really nice to see now the conversion coming in, and also actually pretty much all the divisions are improving in performance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So the fact that the distribution solution is now both revenue and getting better margin is actually a really good situation in the electrification.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Now then if you go a little bit deeper into the market, in Germany we had 8% growth, base order growth was slightly negative.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: There we are seeing a bit of impact in electrification Q3, but we are actually expecting the channel to normalize going into Q4.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And then really the other markets are looking quite strong and I think electrification in And the U.S. was even more than the 30 percent, if I remember correctly.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So these are some of the dynamics on the really, really good performance in electrification.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And we're, of course, super happy about that 18 percent margin there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And we move on with a question for Bjorn from the online tool, and it comes from Phil Buller.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And he says, Bjorn, you're known for being a turnaround guy and it looks like ABB is now turned around.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Is your work done here now or is there more heavy lifting that you can see and wish to progress in the coming years?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Okay, that's an interesting question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But let me start with saying that before I even joined ABB, I always had huge respect for this company.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I said when I came in directly, this is a great company, it has a very strong foundation and we have good people.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I was a little bit puzzled about the financial performance, why we couldnít deliver in line or better than our peers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So that is an important part.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I think weíve taken a giant step on this side and I think we are now coming up to the right levels, but of course, this is only a start of a long journey.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And I believe that ABB has much more potential than this to go forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I'm having my time of the life, so I hope I don't have to leave the company at this stage.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I hope I can continue for a while more while we're having a good time, and the company is a great place to work for.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So, big respect for ABB.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And we'll take another question from the online tool.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Actually, it comes from two people, but on the sort of along the similar lines with our intentions on how to spend the proceeds from the sale of the final 20% of power grids.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: How are you going to spend the cash, boys?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Well, you're sitting on it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Okay, sure, we'll go for that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: No change in our capital allocation principles, so we will continue to look to execute on all of these.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We, of course, first and foremost want to drive organic growth, and then we are expecting to continue to pay sustained growing dividend per share, value-adding acquisitions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We spoke about that a little bit more, how we do that on the divisional ends, and then finally also share buybacks and we should have capacity, as we have discussed earlier, to continue on all of these areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Of course, in the end, it is always a board and AGM decision regarding the share buybacks, but really no change there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We expect to end the year with a strong Q4 cash flow and, of course, adding the power grids money with a strong balance sheet.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Very good.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And we'll take the next question from James Moore at Redburn.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: James, your line should be open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Good morning, everyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: I hope you're well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Could I come back to pricing, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: On revenue price impact, I guess from your peers that you might have been around 2% in PA and RA last quarter, maybe about six or mid-single digit in electrification and motion last quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And I wondered, whatever the numbers were, how that sort of developed in the third quarter and how you expect that to develop into the fourth and into next year, and to what degree average order prices are higher or lower than revenue prices?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Yeah, yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So division, sorry, not division, business area based price levels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So, of course, we are not disclosing this like this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So I can just refer maybe to the to the seven.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So I would say that our shorter cycle businesses were a little higher.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And then, as you say, PA and and are a little lower.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: When we look at the dynamics, what is really, really good to see is that we are actually now covering with pricing all the costs in the cross-margin and a little bit more.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So our cost increase from commodities has started to come down.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Also, the freight actually didn't have a big impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Now, we have a salary inflation on the factories.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: That's understandable.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But the pricing was well covering that, and we had a nice drop through, if I remember, on the EBB level, 23% on the additional revenue.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So in that sense, the equation is working quite well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And then how will this stick, of course, is depending on the demand normalization, which we have been seeing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But I would say that in the shorter cycle business experiences, that it sticks sort of fairly well in this kind of situation, unless we something totally drastic happens.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Well, I can say we also look at the gross margin in our order book, which is of course an important measurement for the future.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And we can of course see that a good strengthening in this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And we believe that the gross margin is of utmost importance for any businesses to be able to develop.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And that is the value you actually you are pricing into your customers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So if you're looking at order book, it looks quite promising.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And if I may, if labor costs, labor inflation goes up, which it looks like it's going to, is that harder to pass on with pricing and requires productivity or can you pass that on?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: I mean, we look at the total cost picture, there's a lot of factors, you know, it's from subsuppliers, it's energy cost, it is freight, everything else that need to be priced in of course.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We have professional pricing departments now in all our divisions and we do expect that they deal with all these kinds of inflation, if it's material or if it's cost increases from labour.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thanks James and we move to Will Mackey at Kepler Shiva.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Hello, good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thank you for the time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The question relates to supply chains and balance sheet.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Primarily, the 1.7 billion of inventory increase in the working capital year to date and the nearly 700 million of trade receivables.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Perhaps you could talk to how you expect the working capital to normalize over the next 12 to 18 months and specifically in the fourth quarter and how that may relate to how you see the evolution of the supply chain.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Yeah, yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thanks for the question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I was kind of expecting that that would come at some point.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So when we look at the inventory, first of all, of course, the most important thing is that the inventory is aligned with the growth we are seeing in the backlog.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And when we look at that measure, i.e. relation with inventory to the backlog, it has actually stayed pretty similar during the last two, three years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So around 30% type of level when we look at it on constant currency.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And if you then look at our order backlog, we are actually expecting more conversion shorter term.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So as we are sitting here and looking at our numbers, we expect about 50% conversion now from current backlog 23.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Last year, we were expecting 45 conversion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So it's actually kind of like coming closer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And in that sense, we think that this is well in line and we would expect the conversion to start to happen now already in Q4, when the demand picture in our expectation will start to normalize.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Now, let's see how that plays out.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And then we expect a strong cash year for 2023, given this continuing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And I can't see any reason why ABB's long term networking capital to revenue would have moved to a higher level from where we have been historically.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So I would expect that number to come down now.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Q4, again, provided we don't have some, let's call it surprise, additional order boost, and then to continue to then further normalize 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And we have one question from Andy here at J.P. Morgan, he says, can you comment on the attractiveness on the pipeline on smaller acquisitions, if that rules out larger deals?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Or are all large deals, no, or are all deal sizes on the table?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Maybe I can talk a little bit about the acquisition side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I think we've been clear that we look at each of the division and we say stability and profitability before growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: About 70% of our divisions are now in what we call growth mode.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And when we talk about growth, it's organic and acquisitions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So we are seeing more and more deals taking place at the moment and we expect this of course to accelerate, 5 to 10 per year is what we think is a reasonable level, of course driven fully from the divisional side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And they are doing it of course to strengthen their competitive situation into the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So it can be technology or market sharing in certain areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The size of these deals are quite small which is natural when it's driven by the divisions but we could of course also see I think at this stage as ABB now is coming into stable and profitability phase maybe somewhat bigger but I'm not saying that we are going to go into any corporate driven by business area driven if there is for instance a smaller division size that could be added on to the business if it strengthens the business area overall.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So, I think we have a pretty good control over this and I think it's a good process at the moment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So, we will experience many small to medium size and maybe some little bit bigger.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And then we take another question from the online tool which says, does the full year 22 margin outlook for at least 15% exclude Acceleron for full year?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Yes, I can answer that one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It is very important when we say that if we will reach our target for this year about 50% then we exclude the Acceleron for the whole year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So that is important and you know that Acceleron has approximately a 0.2 percentage point impact on the group.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And then we'll take another question from the conference call as we open up the line for Joe at Cohen.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Joe, are you with us?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I am, good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: I still struggle with what I see in like larger term macro kind of indicators with what companies are saying with short cycle demand.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: I mean, when I look at orders, you look at things like ISM, I mean, it's in contraction mode, yet companies seem to be talking very positively about short cycle.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: When you look at your own results here, how do you square that?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Are you, do you feel that ABB is significantly outperforming what your competitors are doing?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Is this feel like some sort of inevitable kind of one has to meet the other?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Or do you expect that, like, you could just continue to grow while broader indicators suggest that the markets are going the other way?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Let me talk a little bit about growth and we talked not too much about the expectation going forward, but yeah, we have, I mean, seven quarters with book-to-bill ratio, which is about one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So, So we have seen good growth in the last quarter on very high levels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Of course, now and also when revenues start coming out in the right way, we should see a normalization, I think, of the order pattern going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: It is a little bit too early to say yet, but we look at different kinds of scenarios and we have to play with that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I think ABB is keeping itself well up in relation to competitors.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I don't think we are outperforming probably anyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I think we have a good way to execute and operate and well positioned when we look at the global trends.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So we are where you should be for where we should see growth in the coming years and that is one of the reasons also why we lifted the growth targets over a business cycle to 4% to 7% because we believe that we are in good markets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Then short term of course there will be ups and downs in the market has always been and we need to deal with them and the divisions need to deal with them in a professional way and we do believe that the operating model we have today will do that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So far, I mean, we haven't seen during Q3 any changes in the order or behavior in the buying pattern.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But of course, we read the news, we see what's taking place in the world and we of course expect as everybody else that going forward, we are sure it's going to be some difference what we have seen during the last 6 to 12 months.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And unless I remember wrongly, you can tag on to the question of how has Q4 started because I don't think anyone has asked it yet.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So I will put the question to you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Now we continue to see growth even though we expect a more normalized order pattern during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Right.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And a question from Simon at Jefferies says, can you comment a bit on the end markets in discrete industries where you're seeing customers taking longer to place orders?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I mentioned that a little bit before and that's very much related to the robotic and discrete automation business.

transcript.sentence: You also probably know that these are the two divisions where we have had the biggest challenges when it comes to supply chains and semiconductors part.

transcript.sentence: I mean, I can just mention that our order book here have from one year been 80% up, you know, you can imagine.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: This is, of course, not normal market trend.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So there is, of course, a lot of orders laying there, which was also placed because of our limited possibilities to deliver.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So, of course, that need to be delivered out.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And then we, of course, have to build on the market trends when it comes to automation in the market, which we believe are positive.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And we have actually one, I think, final question here coming through on electrification and the comments about normalization of distributor on inventory levels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: How much of a risk, if any, is this dynamic for demand in the next quarters, given that we say that it seems to be completed by the end of Q3?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Why don't I just say that this comment was specific to Germany and then maybe hand over to Björn.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: This is, of course, we have seen that effect in Germany, especially in electrification where most of the business is handled through our partners and the discussions with them, there is certain normalization of their inventory levels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Talking to our electrification business, this is more or less completed now and we do expect more normal order pattern within that industry going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: This is very specific for Germany, rest of the market as you see on the electrification, besides China, we've seen of course very, very strong growth, not least in North America.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Yes, and then we actually have one last question from the conference call, comes from Daniela Goldman Sachs.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Daniela, your line should be open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: Good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: So following up on the commentary regarding margins and growth going forward, I guess looking from here to 2025, you just said over 15% remains the target, but you seem to lean the commentary in the call a bit more towards growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: Is it fair to say when we think about earnings growth going forward, are there any places where there's significant margin improvement potential left or the opportunity is more the growth side?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Daniela.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I think it's a good question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: As I mentioned here is that our approach is cemented, it's stability, profitability for growth and you have seen more and more division moving in where they have what we call the growth mandate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: That doesn't mean that they're not driving their margins because they continue to improve this and that is part of it but of course, they will also drive growth more stronger.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And today, about 70% of our divisions have what we call the growth mandate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But we still have a number of divisions that are not meeting their expectations for financial performance and they are focusing, of course, to getting the levels to the right level before they really push these kind of businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Of course, we are happy to be on the one year early with reaching the target.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But for us, this is just an in-between target.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We believe that ABB has a great potential.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We will continue to drive that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And for us, it's important to stay above 50% despite different demands in the market if it gets tougher or not.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So we need to make sure that the businesses continue to develop, but also protect the margin in the downturn.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So if it would be a tougher time next year, we do expect that they also should deliver on that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: But we have no roof.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: So they will hopefully continue to improve.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Daniela.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And with that, we close this session.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: We thank you very much for joining us today and we'll see you in about a quarter's time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Bye-bye.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08
